fields.description:
This is really a compatibility/feature request type request.  Additionally,
this is a documentation request as well.  I will attach a child ticket to this
ticket to make sure we document how compatible we are with how AWS handles
Windows support.

  
Andrew and I were checking out if user-data and/or user-data-file is suppose
to work with Windows instances.  Instead, we found this article:

  
http://aws.amazon.com/articles/1767?_encoding=UTF8&jiveRedirect=1

  
There are some interesting sections in here.

  
1)  They have an MSI called EC2config service.  You can download the MSI from
here:

  
http://s3.amazonaws.com/ec2-windows-downloads/Ec2ConfigSetup.msi

  
(I guess this raises the question whether we provide our Windows tool for free
or not).

  
Here is the functionality of the MSI:

  

The images contain one additional service installed by Amazon Web Services,
the EC2 Config Service. This service runs as LocalSystem. The ec2config
service provides the following functionality:

At initial setup

  
* Sets the hostname to the private DNS name

* Generates and sets a random password on the Administrator account

* Initializes and formats the ephemeral disks

* Generates and installs the host certificate used for Terminal Services

* Syncs the instance clock with a time server

  
After initial setup

  
* Writes the last three entries in the System event log to the Amazon EC2 console so you can debug startup problems.

* Prepares instances for bundling

  
We should try and make sure this will work for us as well.  We should probably
have a QA test to test this.  I will create another child ticket for that
request as well.

  
Additionally, we should document what our Windows tool does as well, and give
a comparison chart to EC2config.

  
2) Security Configuration Wizard

  
This is something that AWS recommends.  We may want to reference this as part
of our Windows Image Creation Guide.

  
3) Pagefile Configuration (refer to the URL for more information)

  
4) Server-Authenticated RDP

  
Self-signed certificates are configured on all Windows instances. You can use
these certs to RDP into the instances.  Steps on how to do this are on the
website.

  
5) ec2-get-password

  
Make sure we document whether or not we follow the same semantics for getting
the Admin password for Windows instances.

  
Please let us know if there needs to be any additional information provided.

  
Regards,

--   
Harold L Spencer, Jr.

Technical Support Engineer
